newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle very slow $63 - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle very slow $63 - feedlots.

text.p: CHICAGO, June 6 Reuter) - U.S. Plains feedlot cattle sales near midday Friday were very slow, with not enough traded to adequately test the market, feedlot sources said.
About 400 slaughter heifers that will likely grade select and choice sold at $63.00 per cwt in the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma area following weekly movement of 131,700.
There were no reported sales in Kansas following record large weekly movement of 146,500.
The large weekly sales left most feedlots current but also provided packers with more than enough live inventories for next week, the sources said.

Bids Friday were scattered at $63.00, with some packers reportedly seeking extra days to pick up the cattle, the sources said. Cattle owners were asking mostly $64.00, with a few at $65.00, they said.
Fed cattle prices late this week at $63.00 were down $1.00 from the bulk of cattle sold on Tuesday, down $2.00 from the bulk of last week's sales and down $3.00 from last week's top.

Prices next week were seen pressured by large supplies of market-ready cattle on the way and perceptions that retail beef demand would be light because retailers already had what they needed for Father's Day promotions.
